docs.abstract: Montana (River Steamer) Wrecked by a Storm
docs.lead_paragraph: BISMARCK, Dakota, July 1. An electricstorm, as the Signal Officer calls it, broke upon this city and its vicinity about 7:30 o'clock last evening. It was accompanied by rain and hail and wind, which blew at the rate of 48 miles an hour. A cloud of blinding dust preceded the rain. The storm came from the south, and lasted about an hour.

headline.main: A STEAM-BOAT BLOWN TO PIECES.; SERIOUS DAMAGE BY AN ELECTRIC STORM-IN DAKOTA.

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 23.--Capt. Merritt Thompson, the one-armed pilot, who has saved so many lives at the peril of his own, saw through the rain about 1 P.M. to-day a sunken schooner off the mouth of the harbor, about two miles south of the new light-horse, and some one clinging to the crosstrees. docs.abstract: Ada Iredale, a Burning Wreck Drifts Eight Months

byline.original: From the San Francisco Chronicle, Oct. 18

docs.lead_paragraph: About one year ago the Chronicle published the thrilling narrative of the loss of the British ship Ada Iredale, bound for this port from Ardrossan, with a cargo of coal, and which took fire from spontaneous combustion in the South Pacific. The particulars were obtained from the Captain, who reached this city by a vessel from Tahiti.

headline.main: A FLOATING BURNING HULK.; AN IRON SHIP LOADED WITH COAL DRIFTS FOR EIGHT MONTHS WITH HER CARGO BURNING, AND IS FINALLY TOWED INTO PORT.

byline.original: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times

headline.main: DISASTER ON LAKE MICHIGAN.; A YACHT CAPSIZES OFF CHICAGO--FOUR LIVES LOST.
